title: No 10 says ‘nothing off the table’ over new US tariffs as UK could be among worst hit
partialText: Downing Street says discussions are ongoing following US President Donald Trump's announcement of a 15% global tariffs.

title: Netflix boss defends bid for Warner Bros as Paramount deadline looms
partialText: Ted Sarandos says his company's offer is better for industry growth as it is "buying assets we don't currently have".

title: When is the Spring Statement and what might be in it?
partialText: Chancellor Rachel Reeves will give an update on her plans for the UK economy when she gives a statement alongside an economic forecast on 3 March.

title: US tariff policy 'hasn't changed', says Trump's trade representative
partialText: Jamieson Greer says the legal basis for global import taxes will simply adapt to Friday's Supreme Court ruling.

title: Porn company fined £1.35m by Ofcom over age check failings
partialText: Ofcom's £1.35m fine on 8579 LLC is the largest it has levied under the Online Safety Act so far.

title: Are you cut out for living and working in Antarctica?
partialText: Jobs are available on the icy continent for chefs, plumbers, carpenters and even hairdressers.

title: What now for Asia after Trump's tariffs struck down?
partialText: After the Supreme Court ruling, Trump said he would impose new levies of 15% on goods entering the US.

title: How budget fast fashion is taking small-town India by storm
partialText: More Indians in small towns are now shopping for affordable brands instead of unlabelled goods in the bazaars.

title: The uncertainties facing businesses and consumers after Trump's tariff changes
partialText: Businesses say questions remain after US President Donald Trump announced he will impose global tariffs of 15%.

title: 'It is a catastrophe' - the man battling to stem rising youth unemployment
partialText: Alan Milburn returns to his hometown of Newcastle as he undertakes a review into the growing numbers of young people out of work.

title: Trump says he will increase his new global tariffs to 15%
partialText: After most of his tariffs were outlawed on Friday, Trump announced new global tariffs of 10% - which he says he has now increased to 15%.

title: Is £70 becoming harder to justify? The rise of cheaper blockbuster games
partialText: As top games such as GTA 6 are speculated to cost $100 (£74), some developers are deliberately pricing lower.

title: Trump tariffs ripped up global trade order. What now?
partialText: If you think the Supreme Court ruling heralds a return to pre-Trump business as usual - think again.

title: MPs to discuss inquiry into trade envoy role after Andrew arrest
partialText: A cross-party committee will also look into the appointment and accountability of UK trade envoys.

title: KFC, Nando's, and others ditch chicken welfare pledge
partialText: Wingstop, Burger King, and others have walked away from an industry commitment to avoid using fast-growing chickens

title: Higher tax helped UK government reach record January surplus
partialText: The government took in more from tax receipts than expected, official data suggests.

title: Lobbying firm co-founded by Mandelson goes into administration
partialText: Global Counsel's clients cut ties with the firm over Lord Mandelson's links with sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

title: UK agrees drone defence plan with four EU allies
partialText: The scheme will seek to take inspiration from Ukraine's drone manufacturing programme.

title: Asos co-founder dies after Thailand apartment block fall
partialText: Quentin Griffiths co-founded Asos in 2000 and remained a significant shareholder after leaving the firm five years later.

title: New Year's sport supplement buying adds to January retail sales surge
partialText: Continuing strong sales from online jewellers after a recent spike in gold prices also helped drive the increase.

title: US economy slows in final months after turbulent year
partialText: Overall the economy grew 2.2% last year, holding up despite pressures from changes to tariff and immigration policy.

title: Epstein eyed record label investment to access women, files suggest
partialText: His associate said the music industry was "related to P", a way Epstein apparently often referred to women.

title: Starmer 'appeasing' big tech firms, says online safety campaigner

title: Live Nation sees strong ticket sales as monopoly lawsuit looms
partialText: The entertainment giant's revenue surged last year as 159 million fans attended its concerts.

title: How do you modernise mango farming?
partialText: India's mango farmers are being urged to innovate as climate change makes cultivation "unpredictable".

title: The two farms in Senegal that supply many of the UK's vegetables
partialText: During winter in Britain fresh produce is sent by cargo ship from the West African nation every week.

title: Reddit's human content wins amid the AI flood
partialText: Reddit says its human contributors are valued amid an internet awash with AI-generated content.

title: Trump eyes Venezuela visit – but obstacles to his oil plan remain
partialText: The US president wants American energy firms to start extracting the crude but they are reluctant.

title: Get a grip: Robotics firms struggle to develop hands
partialText: Developing a durable and affordable hand is one of the biggest challenges in robotics.

title: Who is billionaire Sir Jim Ratcliffe and how did he make his money?

title: The US economy is growing - so where are all the jobs?

title: The Dutch love four-day working weeks, but are they sustainable?
partialText: The Netherlands has the lowest working hours in Europe, but some say it is harming its economy.

title: Why food fraud persists, even with improving tech
partialText: Even with sophisticated technology it is still difficult to detect fake foods.

title: Netflix and Paramount are battling for Warner Bros. Who is likely to win?
partialText: What to know about the two firms' blockbuster battle to control Warner Bros Discovery.

title: How £50m 'fish disco' could save farmland
partialText: Innovative tech scares fish away from nuclear cooling pipes.

title: Plane makers chase Asia's super-rich with luxe new private jets
partialText: Parts of the aviation industry are shifting towards wealthy customers and selling a more luxurious type of international travel.

title: 'It's cheaper to ship gluten-free food from the UK'
partialText: A Guernsey mum is calling for cheaper and a greater choice of gluten-free foods for her family.

title: Funding approved to reduce cold deaths

title: Key social issues identified in charity report
partialText: Each year, Citizens Advice selects social policy areas for analysis based on its clients' issues.

title: Rare-breed horse centre cuts back amid cost woes
partialText: The stud continues but a visitor centre and cafe closes as the rare-breed centre takes stock.

title: Higher tax helped UK government reach record January surplus
partialText: The government took in more from tax receipts than expected, official data suggests.

title: The real impact of roadworks on the country - and why they're set to get worse
partialText: There is a fine balance between the benefits of improved infrastructure, versus the cost of disruption. Does the country have it right?

title: Why the railways often seem to be in such chaos over Christmas
partialText: Parts of Britain’s rail network will close for engineering work over the festive period - but is that the right time to do it?

title: Budget 2025: What's the best and worst that could happen for Labour?

title: Has Britain's budget watchdog become too all-powerful?
